article.title: Low-Speed Clinorotation of Brachypodium distachyon and Arabidopsis thaliana Seedlings Triggers Root Tip Curvatures That Are Reminiscent of Gravitropism

funding.text: National Aeronautics and Space Administration (grant number 80NSSC18K1481)

article.abstract: Clinostats are instruments that continuously rotate biological specimens along an axis, thereby averaging their orientation relative to gravity over time.

sections.introduction: Most plants use gravitropism to guide the growth of their organs, directing primary roots vertically downward into the soil, primary shoots upward above ground, and secondary organs laterally, at an angle from the vertical named the gravity set point angle (GSA), to effectively explore their immediate surroundings.
sections.methods: Seeds of Arabidopsis thaliana accessions Col and Ws (originally received from ABRC, Columbus, OH, USA) and of Brachypodium distachyon Bd21-3 and Ron-2 accessions (received from the Amasino laboratory at the University of Wisconsin–Madison) were used as experimental materials in this study.
sections.results: In the first assay, Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings growing on the surface of an agar-based medium in Petri dishes were subjected to low-speed (0.2 RPM) vertical clinorotation in clockwise or counterclockwise directions.
sections.discussion: Considering that repeated short periods of gravistimulation can trigger a gravitropic response, we wanted to reassess the assumption that low-speed clinorotation truly simulates weightlessness.

experimental_factors.tissue: root, root cap, shoot, starch sheath, columella cells
experimental_factors.tissue_raw: root, root cap, shoot, starch sheath, columella cells

article.insights_summary: Low-speed clinorotation triggers root tip curvature in Arabidopsis thaliana and Brachypodium distachyon seedlings, reminiscent of gravitropism. The direction of curvature is dictated by gravitropism during the first half-turn of clinorotation.
article.acknowledgments: We thank Daniel Woods from Rick Amasino’s laboratory and Marisa Otegui for the generous gift of plant materials.
